title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [4? november 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [4? November 1868]
text: 11 Nov. '68wensdayWednesdaymy dear Walteri received your letter yesterday it is the first i believe that i have got on tuesdayTuesday but i am very thankfullthankful to get them wensdayWednesday i should have written immediately and told you the letter and 2 dollrdollars came safe but i was fixing georgesgeorge's things a little as he has gone to camdenCamden to the foundry he and mrMr. Lane went last night in the 6 oclocko'clock train georgyGeorgey didentdidn't want to go much i dontdon't think it was on my account but georgyGeorgey is very much carried away by somebody who it is is best known to himself he gets 5 dollardollars per day and his expencesexpenses paid to the city once a month if he comes oftener he pays his own way he said he should come 2 weeks from next saturdaySaturday i think sometimes itsit's a pity such a good man as georgeGeorge would be) he is good to me but he seems to be so close with his moneeymoney maybeemaybe he has uses for it that i little know he pays the rent and when i ask him for ten ctscents he gives it to me but he used to be so different well waltWalt we all change some for better and some for worsei was so glad to get your letter waltWalt yesterday i have not got any houshouse yet mattsMatt's got a letter from jeffJeff mondayMonday and a check for 50 dollars and yesterday she got one from Worthen for 200 dollars for JeffsJeff's servisesservices in the board of health and there is one hundred more to come to Jeff georgeGeorge brought the check up for the 200 hundred and said there was another hundred to come i said to georgeGeorge when i give matt this check she will say when will she get the other sure enoughfenough i gave her the 200 dollerdollar check and she said she wished they would hurry up and pay the other hundred i said i told georgeGeorge you would want the other and you didentdidn't know you was going to have any so waltWalt you see folks changes) but waltWalt i think you and your old mother is about as reliable and good as you can find) mat is waiting to take the letter i have got a very bad cold and am pretty lame but i must bear itgood bie walterWalter deartake good care of yourself the next i will write about domestic affairs Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [4? November 1868]
